prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO 6-5 at z=1.75
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This program will target CO(6-5) in cluster galaxies at z=1.75.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose spectral line observations of CO (6-5) in Band 6 for 16 point source targets. This transition is the lowest available for this cluster at z=1.75. This band is also optimal as the continuum observations probe a different wavelength than the submillimeter data currently available, allowing us to put constraints on the shape of the spectral energy distribution (SED). The primary baseband is tuned to cover the CO (6-5) line at z=1.75 (vobs = 251 GHz). The remaining basebands are spaced to cover the majority of remaining bandwidth (aggregate bandwidth: 7.13 GHz) for a deep continuum image. The ACA is not requested and no special considerations for bandpass accuracy or data rate are required.
We request compact configuration C34-2 (~1 arcsec resolution) since this mitigates shadowing for our high declination targets. This resolution is sufficient to deblend nearby sources from the Spitzer images, but is not so high that we resolve our targets. We choose a standard calibration for this project and have no time constraints.
Our target sensitivity is driven by the depth needed to detect CO (6-5) in cluster galaxies with SFR>100 Msun/yr, as determined by PACS. We determine our target sensitivity by taking typical values of the conversion from CO (6-5) to CO (1-0) and of LIR/LCO from measurement of galaxies detected at 850um (Bothwell et al.~2012) to calculate that to reach 100 Msun/yr (7x10^11 Lsun), we need a 1sigma sensitivity of 0.33 mJy per 300 km/s channel at 251 GHz. The peak flux density is 1.33 mJy. This will result in a 4sigma detection of the CO (6-5) line, sufficient to spectroscopically confirm the redshift of cluster galaxies. Continuum measurements will reach a 1sigma sensitivity of 0.06 mJy with a SNR~30. For 16 targets, the OT estimates 3 hours, including 2 hours on source and 1 hour of overheads.
Though IDCS J1426.5+3508 is located at relatively high declination, is stays above 30 degrees for ~3 hours per night, allowing this program to be accomplished in a single night.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe the molecular gas in the most massive cluster known to date at z>1.4. IDCS 1426.5+3508 lies at z=1.75, during an epoch of active star formation and evolution in the densest environments. With a mass of 5e14 Msun, this cluster will evolve into one of the most massive clusters in the Universe, presenting the unique opportunity to study an extreme structure prior to quenching. With this small program, we will observe the redshifted CO line emission in cluster galaxies down to SFR~100 Msun/yr in order to confirm cluster membership and measure a statistical velocity dispersion for the star-forming cluster galaxy population. Targeting this galaxy population is a unique demonstration of ALMA's capabilities, as UV/optical spectroscopy are often biased against dusty systems. In addition, we will 1) examine the properties of excited gas in cluster galaxies, and 2) use the deep continuum image to localize and quantify the dust for cluster galaxies and additional galaxies within the ALMA beam. This short (~3 hour) program will constrain the role of environment in shaping the observed properties of galaxies during a crucial epoch of active cluster evolution.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
